trans-unit.source: Represents a MIME protocol Content-Type header.
The information in the ContentType class is used to describe the data contained in an e-mail message in such a way that software that displays e-mail can present the content in an appropriate manner.
ContentType is used with the <xref:System.Net.Mail.Attachment> class to specify the type of content in the attachment.
The syntax of the Content-Type header is described in RFC 2045 Section 5.1.
RFC 2046 provides detailed information about MIME media types and their parameters.
These RFCs are available at [http://www.ietf.org](http://www.ietf.org/).
Initializes a new default instance of the <xref href="System.Net.Mime.ContentType"></xref> class.
This constructor initializes the <xref:System.Net.Mime.ContentType.MediaType%2A> property to `"application/octet-stream"`.
Initializes a new instance of the <xref href="System.Net.Mime.ContentType"></xref> class using the specified string.
The syntax of the `contentType` string is described in RFC 2045 Section 5.1 available at [http://www.ietf.org](http://www.ietf.org/).
A <xref:System.String>, for example, `"text/plain; charset=us-ascii"`, that contains the MIME media type, subtype, and optional parameters.
contentType is .
contentType is ("").
contentType is in a form that cannot be parsed.
Gets or sets the value of the boundary parameter included in the Content-Type header represented by this instance.
In the following example of a Content-Type header, the value of the Boundary parameter is "`-----boundary---0`".
`content-type: multipart/mixed; boundary=-----boundary---0` Set this property to `null` or <xref:System.String?displayProperty=fullName> to remove the boundary information from the header.
The syntax of the Content-Type header is described in RFC 2045 Section 5.1.
An in-depth discussion of the boundary parameter is contained in RFC 2046 Section 5.1.1.
These RFCs are available at [http://www.ietf.org](http://www.ietf.org/).
A <xref:System.String> that contains the value associated with the boundary parameter.
Gets or sets the value of the charset parameter included in the Content-Type header represented by this instance.
In the following example of a Content-Type header, the value of the CharSet property is "`us-ascii`".
`content-type: application/x-myType; charset=us-ascii` Set this property to `null` or <xref:System.String?displayProperty=fullName> to remove the charset information from the header.
A grammar that details the syntax of the Content-Type header is described in RFC 2045 Section 5.1.
An in-depth discussion of the charset parameter is contained in RFC 2046 Section 4.1.2.
These RFCs are available at [http://www.ietf.org](http://www.ietf.org/).
A <xref:System.String> that contains the value associated with the charset parameter.
Determines whether the content-type header of the specified <xref href="System.Net.Mime.ContentType"></xref> object is equal to the content-type header of this object.
The <xref href="System.Net.Mime.ContentType"></xref> object to compare with this object.
<xref uid="langword_csharp_true" name="true" href=""></xref> if the content-type headers are the same; otherwise <xref uid="langword_csharp_false" name="false" href=""></xref>.
Determines the hash code of the specified <xref href="System.Net.Mime.ContentType"></xref> object
An integer hash value.
Gets or sets the media type value included in the Content-Type header represented by this instance.
In the following example of a Content-Type header, the value of the MediaType property is `"application/x-myType"`.
`content-type: application/x-myType; name=data.xyz` Set this property to `null` or <xref:System.String?displayProperty=fullName> to remove the name information from the header.
The syntax of the Content-Type header is described in RFC 2045 Section 5.1.
RFC 2046 provides detailed information on MIME media types.
These RFCs are available at [http://www.ietf.org](http://www.ietf.org/).
A <xref:System.String> that contains the media type and subtype value.
This value does not include the semicolon (;) separator that follows the subtype.
The value specified for a set operation is <xref uid="langword_csharp_null" name="null" href=""></xref>.
The value specified for a set operation is <xref:System.String> ("").
The value specified for a set operation is in a form that cannot be parsed.
Gets or sets the value of the name parameter included in the Content-Type header represented by this instance.
In the following example of a Content-Type header, the value of the Name property is `"data.xyz"`.

`content-type: application/x-myType; name=data.xyz` A grammar that details the syntax of the Content-Type header is described in RFC 2045 Section 5.1, available at [http://www.ietf.org](http://www.ietf.org/).

When specifying content for a <xref:System.Net.Mail.Attachment> as a <xref:System.IO.Stream> or <xref:System.String>, you can use Name to set the name of the file that stores the content on the recipient's system.
A <xref:System.String> that contains the value associated with the name parameter.
Gets the dictionary that contains the parameters included in the Content-Type header represented by this instance.

You can set the parameters by specifying the entire Content-Header value when constructing a <xref:System.Net.Mime.ContentType> object or you can add parameters to the <xref:System.Collections.Specialized.StringDictionary> returned by the Parameters property.
When adding a parameter entry to the dictionary, the name of the parameter is the entry's key and the value of the parameter is the entry's value.
A grammar that details the syntax of the Content-Type header is described in RFC 2045 Section 5.1.
RFC 2046 provides detailed information on MIME media types and their associated parameters.
These RFCs are available at [http://www.ietf.org](http://www.ietf.org/).
A writable <xref href="System.Collections.Specialized.StringDictionary"></xref> that contains name and value pairs.
Returns a string representation of this <xref href="System.Net.Mime.ContentType"></xref> object.
The value of the ToString method contains the string used to create this <xref:System.Net.Mime.ContentType>, if one was specified and no property values have been changed.

If no string was specified, or one or more property values have changed since this <xref:System.Net.Mime.ContentType> was created, the value of ToString is a string in the format of a Content-Type header that is composed using the current property values.
The string does not include the `"Content-type:"` prefix.
The syntax of the Content-Type header is described in RFC 2045 Section 5.1, available at [http://www.ietf.org](http://www.ietf.org/).
A <xref:System.String> that contains the current settings for this <xref href="System.Net.Mime.ContentType"></xref>.
